posts.name:
Megan Lieu
Megan Lieu
posts.content:
I walked into my termination meeting at my last job thinking I was getting a promotion.

I remember sitting in a cafe that Friday for the 4:30 pm call, which started off like any other weekly check-in with my manager.

Until we were at 10 minutes left in the call.

“That’s why we’ve decided we’re parting ways with you, effective immediately after this call.”

Those words echoed in the silence as I was at a loss for words, a loss for any feeling at all.

Because my expectation that I was going to bring up my promotion during this call was so different from this reality.

When I could finally muster up the ability to speak, I blubbered out something like “Thank you for the opportunity to work with you guys.”

Even though what I really wanted to say was “Why? Why was I given no heads up at all?”

What I really wanted to do was to fight for myself, but what society tells us to do is to end things with dignity and not burn any bridges.

So that’s what I did. I stayed silent, until now.

I’ve stayed silent that I was actually so bitter and traumatized about how I was let go for many months afterward.

It wasn’t until recently that I’ve found closure by realizing it was precisely the difference between my own expectations vs reality that was the root of my pain:

I falsely thought I was doing a great job and my role was safe because I was 1 out of 6 people in the company, but the truth was the complete opposite.

For most people dealing with job loss during this recession, it is not your fault nor could you have done anything to prevent it.

But if there is one grave mistake you can prevent, it’s being foolish enough to believe in the myth of job security.

If you found this post valuable, make sure you reshare and followfor more!

posts.name:
Ranveer Allahbadia
Ranveer Allahbadia
posts.content:
Dear soul reading this,
According to numerology, 2024 has been a year governed by Saturn.

Saturn tests two aspects of your existence :
1. Your ability to work hard through storms.
2. Your ability to stay humble through glory.

Saturn is a task master. Saturn is an examiner.

It's not been an easy year for me either. I have put my head down and worked through it all.

Some times, while my head was down and working... my eyes teared up with the pressure of being an adult.

Some times while my head was down and working... God gave me moments to smile & breathe.

It's been a year that's tested me to my last degree of resistance.

It's a year that's taught me : Faith and belief can overcome the false storms of what we call "suffering"

My knee injury was a gift as much as my national award was.

My poor mental health was a gift as much as public adulation was.

Life's purpose is to grow. Often through the dungeons of suffering as much as through the dungeons of success.

Get even healthier this year.
Meditate deeply this year.
Pursue peace this year.

But whatever you do, believe that God is with you through every step.

Happy 2025, have a blessed one!

2025 - Year of "Mars"

Pour your intensity into the speed and strength of your work.
Now overcome your own demons.
Now grow more easily.

posts.name:
Nuwpur Jain
Nuwpur Jain
posts.content:
My dadi died 7 days back BUT she lived an absolutely full life which shocks me even today

Here's what made her extraordinary:

1) The Family Matriarch: She nurtured an incredible legacy of 51 hearts - 6 children, 18 grandchildren, and 27 great-grandchildren. Each one carrying a piece of her boundless love.

2) The Eternal Explorer: At 80+, she had the curiosity of a 21-year-old, traveling from Singapore to Dubai, and finally to Ram Mandir - living life with more enthusiasm than people a quarter her age.

3) The Graceful Goodbye: Seven days ago, she left us exactly how she lived - peacefully, having fulfilled all her wishes, and without suffering. A perfect ending to a life lived perfectly.

Here's to you, Dadi - forever young, forever loved ️

comments.commentText: Nuwpur, your tribute to your grandmother beautifully captures the essence of a remarkable life well-lived. Her legacy of love and curiosity is truly inspiring and serves as a reminder of how to embrace life fully, regardless of age. Thank you for sharing such heartfelt memories.
Priyank Ahuja Living proof that the best things in life come without an expiry date

𝐌𝐲 𝐜𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐝𝐨𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐞𝐫—𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭’𝐬 𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐩𝐩𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐲𝐨𝐮?

Here’s the thing: More hustle isn’t the answer.
You don’t need to pull all-nighters, take on more clients, or constantly grind to see real results.

What you do need is;

 A clear strategy that works for YOU and YOUR business ( this isn’t one size fits all)
 Systems that let you work smarter, not harder.
 A brand that attracts the right opportunities effortlessly.

That’s exactly what I help my clients achieve—and the results speak for themselves:
 Business owners landing dream clients they thought were out of reach.
 Professionals doubling their income in months, not years.
 Entrepreneurs creating more freedom while working less.

The best part? You don’t have to reinvent the wheel or wait for “someday.” It’s about making the right moves on LinkedIn now.

So, let me ask you:
What’s stopping you from taking the next step?

If you’re ready to scale without sacrificing your sanity, let’s chat. Drop me a DM or comment “Neft step!” below, and let’s build the business (and life) you’ve been working so hard for.

posts.name:
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
posts.content:
I have an impossible goal for 2025, and I want to share the questions I answered to create it. 

Sometimes, I think I should call myself the Possibilities Coach. I've studied the science of impossible goal setting and believe in my heart that every wild, impossible goal is hidden behind false assumptions of what we believe to be true.

Last week, I gave my Impossible Possibilities workshop to members of The Upside; this question generated the most energy among nearly 70 members.

What are the characteristics and qualities of the person who could achieve your impossible goal?

When you match the process of believing in your impossibility with IDC (Intentional, Discipline, Consistency) you, your team and your organization can achieve the impossible.

Musk, Bezos, and Oprah are no different than you or me - they imagined an impossible goal, built belief, and took massive action.

The Four Step Process:
- Define your impossible goal – something that scares you but excites you even more
- Question your basic assumptions about who you serve, how you operate, and what defines success
- Identify the person you need to become to achieve this goal
- Find the "WHOs" – the people who can help make your impossible possible
- Commit to taking bold action, even when (especially when) failure feels likely

At, we go deep into the process to reverse engineer goal setting and success with teams and talent. Setting impossible goals is a process of unlocking awareness (around assumptions and the past) and allowing for inspired thinking for a better way forward. If you want to learn more about the process or want to host a team workshop to create the impossible goal, please shoot us a DM.

[Thanks tofor attending the workshop and creating this image of the process!]

comments.commentText: Great question!! I see why it was the one that resonated most!
Taylor Buonocore-Guthrie Coming from the Champion of the Best Questions, that's a compliment! Thanks Taylor.

The reason I love it so much is that it has a root question within it that could be used with pretty much any group. 

For an individual it's What are the characteristics and qualities of the person who could achieve your impossible goal?

For a team working together on something it's What are the characteristics and qualities of a team who [fill in team's goal here].
This is such a great question--it resonates with me. Adding it to my evening reflection!
Frenchie Ferenczi let me know what you learn! Have fun with it.

posts.name:
Mike Leber
Mike Leber
posts.content:
Companies Push Back Against Remote Work

But where you work is not the question:

These 16 traits set top-performing organizations apart:

1. They value trust over control.
↳ Micromanagement kills morale. Trust sparks innovation.

2. They value outcomes, not hours.
↳ Results matter more than a 9-to-5 routine.

3. They listen to employees’ needs.
↳ Engaged teams outperform pressured ones.

4. They protect deep work.
↳ Meaningful work happens when interruptions are minimized.

5. They encourage autonomy.
↳ Freedom to work your way drives accountability and creativity.

6. They prioritize collaboration over surveillance.
↳ Teams thrive with connection, not constant monitoring.

7. They hire for trust and culture fit.
↳ Great teams don’t need to be babysat - they’re aligned on values.

8. They adapt, not enforce rigid policies.
↳ Flexibility attracts top talent and retains them.

9. They support hybrid models when needed.
↳ The right mix of in-office and remote boosts connection and productivity.

10. They invest in meaningful communication tools.
↳ Slack, Zoom, and async updates beat endless in-person meetings.

11. They align on purpose, not location.
↳ Shared goals create unity, regardless of geography.

12. They see remote work as a skill, not a perk.
↳ It’s about mastering focus and self-management.

13. They reward outcomes, not presenteeism.
↳ Showing up doesn’t equal productivity. Delivering results does.

14. They address struggles with support, not suspicion.
↳ Struggling employees need clarity and guidance - not blame.

15. They equip leaders to manage remotely.
↳ Great managers lead teams, not desks.

16. They measure engagement, not office attendance.
↳ Happy, motivated employees stay, wherever they work.

This isn’t about remote work!

It’s about trust, autonomy, and outcomes.

The future belongs to companies that treat their people like pros.

Which of these traits resonates with you the most?
Let me know below ⬇️

️ Followand reshare to help others.
 Save this post for future reference!⁣⁣⁣⁣

comments.commentText: This is great Mike Leber! The future of work isn’t about location, but trust, support, and empowerment. One trait I value is valuing outcomes over hours. It focuses on results, not clock-watching, and drives productivity.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

posts.name:
Kyle Asay
Kyle Asay
posts.content:
I love having Sales Introverts + being a senior sales leader. 

I hope to be an example that:

1) You can do meaningful work for an employer while also building something you own

Since joining LD, my orgs have made significant transformations in key metrics. My remit is significantly growing entering next year, despite only being here 7 months.

My work on Sales Introverts doesn't come at the expense of LaunchDarkly. It accentuates my impact.

If Sales Introverts got in the way of my work, I’d be told to “stop or you’ll be fired.”

Trust me, CEOs and CROs don’t have any tolerance for poor performing senior sales leaders, especially if they think their performance suffers because of distractions.


2) Your impact doesn’t have to be limited to your company

Here is feedback received just in the last few days from sellers taking my programs:

“Took the whole class Tuesday night and generated the two largest cold opps of my career in two days, one that might close this quarter due to the creating the PoV video”

“Genuinely SO glad I opened that promo email. I’m pretty obsessed with the whole framework you’ve built, Kyle. Big fan over here. I just wish you were funnier…” (can’t do it all, I guess)

“I took your framework to heart and ended up at 200% of goal in my first full Q.”

I never would have talked to these sellers without my work on Sales Introverts, much less helped them progress their careers.


3) Sellers should find leaders that want to develop them

Some of my best AEs applied to work with me after first taking one of my programs. Seeing my approach to development has been my number one selling point as a sales leader.

Without my work on Sales Introverts, these AEs would have no idea who I am, and I wouldn’t be able to attract the caliber of talent I need to win.

There’s plenty of time in a week to put my all into my “real job” and progress Sales Introverts.

It’s meant giving up some other hobbies but it’s been well worth it.
